Award.AwardTitle: A Modern Evolvable Architecture for Spectrum Regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study how to engineer modern spectrum sharing systems. Wireless spectrum is now recognized as a key national resource that has to be managed appropriately to support innovation and economic growth. Traditional wireless rules were written by a combination of lawyers and engineers in legal English, and read/interpreted by lawyers and engineers. The emerging revolution in wireless regulation is that the core rules will be embedded in automated Spectrum Access Systems (SASs) that are implemented in a combination of hardware, software, and interaction protocols. Moreover, the SASs will support diverse wireless systems ranging from legacy federal users to traditional cellular carriers to emerging new innovative wireless systems. The ideas developed in this project will be disseminated to industry as well as brought into the classroom, including our new Masters of Engineering courses aimed at educating innovative technical leaders. The project will also broaden participation in the technical workforce by mentoring students from underrepresented groups.

At its technical core, this project will help create a modern theory of how to make scalable and robust SASs by bringing together a combination of software engineering, mathematical wireless theory, as well as an understanding of the policy tradeoffs that we want to support. The key realization is that making scalable systems is about robustly approximating what we want in a safe manner while supporting flexibility. Ideas from virtualization, software-defined-networking, and cloud computing will play an important role. In addition to getting a handle on what the overall architecture should be of our SAS-enabled wireless future, the project will also take insights and embody them into easy-to-use prototype tools that can be adapted by federal regulators and spectrum managers to explore and navigate the design tradeoffs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless spectrum is incredibly important as a key shared resource that underlies our modern age. However, it is used by diverse uses and so understanding how to share it in the best manner is far from obvious. This project set out to establish the foundations of new, more modern, and flexible technological approaches to share spectrum that would simultaneously promote innovation while also protecting the heterogenous uses of spectrum that will continue to exist in the future. This required brigning together technological and scientific ideas with economic ones. In particular, because we wanted to support innovation, we needed to understand whether light-handed approaches to regulation could succeed and what technological supports they would need. After all, human beings don't see, touch, hear, taste, or smell wireless signals and the time-scales involved in their use can be much smaller than human time-scales, while the geographic extent can range from small to continental scale. These technological characteristics do not necessarily play well with traditional approaches to regulation, and the impending era of machine learning and AI meant that the tension is going to grow not dissipate.

In response to this need, we established the foundations of light-handed regulation and spectrum rights using a novel model of "spectrum jails" that involved purely technological enforcement mechanisms that could be reliably deployed at machine time and spatial scales without needing human lawyers to be involved with every enforcement action. This recognized that such automated systems of the future would have their own internal incentives driven by the nature of wireless use and thus, there might be a way to avoid having to use human level incentives and money. Here, we wanted to flesh out how we can avoid making the perfect the enemy of the good ---- all systems are going to be imperfect, so we need to understand the tradeoffs between different dimensions of imperfection.

At the same time, we needed to make sure that our understanding of intrinsic wireless incentives and sensitivities wasn't dominated by just the traditional example of cellular or broadcast communication. So, we explored the fundamental sensitivities of a very different more time-critical application inspired by industrial control for agile manufacturing (e.g. smart factories or robots). We saw how demanding high-performance applications are, and how they can deal with uncertainty in the environment. Here, learning is clearly important since that is how systems deal with in-situ uncertaintly.

Consequently, both of these streams of research ended up having to consider how learning interacts with systems of this nature. Somewhat surprisingly, we found ourselves having to tackle fundamental questions at the intersection of learning, economics, and wireless to make progress. We found that the classical economic concept of equilibrium is sensitive to the need to learn, and that the idea of credibility and commitment itself has degrees to it. We understood that there was a need to balance paranoia (in case we are dealing with a truly adversarial environment) with careful learning (in case the environment is merely complex). We found that wireless systems can use learning to improve their performance but also that learning is no magic bullet.
